Award.AwardTitle: Excited State Electronic Structure and Dynamics in Branched Conjugated Molecules Using Exciton Scattering Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
Vladimir Chernyak of Wayne State University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program for research to develop efficient quasiparticle methods for excited states electronic structure in conjugated molecules, with the special focus on the coupling between electronic and vibrational motions. The main goal will be achieved by: (i) introducing reduced tight-binding (lattice) models, where excitons for ideal geometries are represented by the states of a quantum particle that resides on an effective irregular lattice, (ii) accounting for geometry distortions via the dependence of the tight-binding parameters on molecular geometry. The proposed research will improve the microscopic insights into photoinduced dynamics and develop efficient models of the energy transfer processes in branched conjugated structures, including those related to solar energy conversion in organic and hybrid photovoltaic materials.

Organic conjugated photovoltaic materials as well as organic-inorganic hybrid composites form a promising new direction towards development of cost-effective solar cells. The proposed exciton scattering can be used as basis for a modeling tool for efficient design of organic-based low-cost materials with prominent photophysical and transport properties. This will benefit society at large by contributing to modern technologies including solar energy conversion, organic light-emitting diodes, imaging devices, and chemical and biological sensors. The quasiparticle insight is likely to lead to new developments in statistical inference, algorithms, quantum/stochastic dynamics in networks, including a very important application to the design of smart power grids. Chernyak is collaborating with the Department of Mathematics at WSU to expose math graduate students to research in physical chemistry, and with LANL to increase the impact of the NSF-funded research on nanotechnological developments, as well as to provide students with a first-hand and broad picture of the nanotechnological needs in terms of fundamental research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large organic molecules and conjugated structures represent a class of materials that are interesting both from the fundamental research viewpoint, as well as for practical applications. The fundamental character of organic systems is due to a small number of building blocks (mostly carbon, hydrogen and oxygen atoms) with a huge variety in their chemical, photochemical, and dynamical properties, depending on the connectivity. In our earlier research we have developed a multiscale approach, coined the Exciton Scattering (ES) method that combines a capability to perform precise calculations of the excited state electronic structure and optical/spectroscopic properties in branched conjugated structures of practically unlimited size with providing a microscopic insight into the structure of electronic excitations (excitons). However, the ES method can be applied only to ideal molecular geometries, whereas the geometry distortions play crucial role in vibrational relaxation (also known as incoherent energy transfer) of a photoexcited molecule. We have extended the capability of the ES approach to distorted geometries. This was achieved by introducing the effective tight-binding (lattice) models that have a small number of parameters, referred to as on-site energies and hopping constants. We have identified the dependence of the model parameters on the molecular geometry by treating localized geometry distortions as scattering centers for excitons, thus completely describing the coupling between electron and nuclear motions.

Stochastic dynamics that provides an adequate, efficient, and computationally feasible description of a molecular system, coupled to macroscopic  environment, and therefore plays a central role in chemistry in condensed phase, in particular of biological systems. We have studied stochastic motion of extended (higher-dimensional) objects. This naturally led us to introducing a new concept of higher fluxes that provide additional measures of how far a system is driven out of equilibrium. We found that the low-temperature limit of the aforementioned stochastic dynamics can be adequately described using a new class of discrete models that can be viewed as higher-dimensional analogues of networks, with the links being associated with a broader class of transition states.

 On the broader impact side, the microscopic dynamical insight into excited state electronic structure in conjugated systems, and most importantly the coupling between electronic and nuclear motions, will assist in developing and engineering of high-performing and inexpensive organic-based photovoltaic materials, in particular with applications to efficient solar energy conversion. The newly discovered links between non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, stochastic optimal control, and algebraic topology, identified in studying stochastic motion of extended objects, specifically in the low-temperature limit, provides new ways to study delicate topological invariants of smooth manifolds, using methods of statistical physics and physical chemistry.

 A combination of expertise in theoretical femtosecond nonlinear spectroscopy, physical chemistry, mathematical and theoretical condensed matter physics, statistical mechanics, and computational methodology, offered in the PI’s research group, provides students with a unique set of theoretical/computational skills  in developing theoretical approaches to dynamical and transport phenomena in conjugated systems and networks.
